title: How much food do you waste?
intro: In this programme, Neil and Dan discuss how food waste could cause the end of the world, and who's doing something about it. And they teach you six items of useful vocabulary
this_week_question: How much of the world’s food is wasted each year?
Listen to the programme to find out the answer.

vocab.desc: something you throw away or lose without using or consuming
the remains of food or a meal, which have not been eaten
a place where rubbish is dropped or buried
well-known by ordinary people of a particular place or culture
the basic systems and services of a society

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Hello and welcome to 6 Minute English– the show that brings you an interesting topic, authentic listening practice and six new items of vocabulary. I'm Dan…

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: And I’m Neil. In this episode we’ll be discussing food waste, just as soon as….

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Neil, did you just throw the rest of that apple away?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yeah. It was quite a big one and I couldn’t finish it.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Neil, you know you shouldn’t waste food.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Waste meaning to throw away without consuming or using.  Ah, it’s only an apple. It’s not the end of the world, Dan.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, that’s where you could be wrong, my friend. Let me prove it to you, with this week’s question. How much of the world’s food is wasted each year?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I’m not sure. I know it’s a lot so I’m going to say a) a half

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: We’ll find out if you’re right or not at the end of this show. So, the actual figure is 1.3 billion tons of food, which is enough to feed a billion hungry people. Where do you think all this food waste comes from?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, restaurants, I imagine. I mean, they can’t give one customer’s leftovers to another! That would be unhygienic!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Leftovers are the remains of food which has not been eaten. And while you are right, restaurants are not the main contributor to food waste.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Supermarkets! I bet they throw out loads of food once it goes past its sell-by-date, or the date which it can be legally sold by.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Think closer to home.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: It’s us, isn’t it?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Yes. In Europe an incredible 53% of food waste comes from households, which results in 88 million tonnes of food waste a year. And I bet you can’t guess what we do with it?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I want to say recycle, but I can see from your face, Dan, that it’s not.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: No. Unfortunately it goes into landfills and decays.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: A landfill is a place where rubbish is buried. I see, so the food rots and this causes greenhouse gasses which lead to global warming and climate change.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Exactly, and the end of the world. But, remarkably the European country of Denmark has managed to reduce its food waste by a very significant 25%

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: That’s impressive, how did that happen?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: They attribute it to a woman called Selina Juul.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I’ve heard about her. She became a household name in Denmark overnight!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: A household name is one which everybody knows, and that’s right.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: I thought she was Russian?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: She is. But, I’ll let her explain.

transcript.author: INSERT
transcript.text: Selina Juul I come from a country where there were food shortages, back then in Moscow, communism collapsed, we had the collapse of infrastructure , we were not sure we could get food on the table. And coming to Denmark, seeing this abundance , seeing these supermarkets filled with food. But then I was really shocked to see a lot of food getting wasted.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So Selina grew up in Moscow at a time when there wasn’t enough food because of the collapse of infrastructure , meaning the basic systems and services of a society – such as food transportation.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Then when she moved to Denmark, she found an abundance , or more than enough, food, but she saw it being wasted.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: So she decided to do something about it?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Yes. She started a Facebook page in 2008 called ‘stop wasting food’ and 9 years later the Danish government credits her for their reduction in food waste.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: How did she do it?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Well, lots of ideas really. She convinced some supermarkets to stop selling their items in bulk so that people buy only what they need. She’s produced a leftovers cookbook and she’s working with three governments to set up an education programme in schools.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Wow, she’s a busy woman. So how about you educate me with the answer to this week’s question.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Sure! I asked you how much of the world’s food is wasted each year?
c) a quarter Neil And I said a) a half

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And I’m terribly sorry, mate, but you’re wrong. The answer is b) a third.

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, it’s not as bad as I thought it was, at least.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Shall we look at the vocabulary then?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Yes, let’s. First we had waste . If you waste something, you throw it away or lose it without using it or consuming it. Common things we waste are food, time, money and energy. We also have some expressions with waste too. Can you think of one, Dan?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: A waste of space is an expression which means a thing is completely without value. For example, I’m a complete waste of space in the kitchen. I can’t cook at all. Next we had leftovers. Leftovers are the remains of food or a meal, which have not been eaten. What do you tend to do with your leftovers , Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh I love leftovers ! Sometimes I think they taste even better than the original meal!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: I agree! Pizza’s a great example!

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Then we had landfill . A landfill is a place where rubbish is dropped and buried. In colloquial English we might say, a dump . Do you ever take your rubbish to the dump , Dan?

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: Not if I can help it. I prefer to recycle as much as possible. I only go to the dump if I have to get rid of a large appliance, such as a fridge. Then we had a household name . To be a household name is to be well-known by ordinary people of a particular place or culture. Can you think of a person who is a household name at the moment, Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Oh, that’s very easy. Donald Trump springs to mind! Everyone must know who he is. Then we had infrastructure . Infrastructure is the basic systems and services of a society – such as electricity supply, trains, and roads.

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And finally we had abundance . If you have an abundance of something, you have more than you need. Do have anything in abundance , Neil?

transcript.author: Neil
transcript.text: Well, when it comes to my children I have to have an abundance of patience….well, most of the time. And, that's the end of today's 6 Minute English. Please join us again soon!

transcript.author: Dan
transcript.text: And we are on social media too - Facebook, Twitter, Instagram and YouTube. See you there.

transcript.author: Both
transcript.text: Bye!
